content.card_other: Light is electromagnetic wave with wavelength range ~400-700 nm (visible spectrum). Exhibits wave properties: interference, diffraction, polarization. Does not require medium, travels through vacuum.
Fundamental constant c = 3.00 × 10⁸ m/s in vacuum. Reduces in material media. Constant in vacuum regardless of source motion or observer (relativity). Fastest possible speed in universe.
Range of all electromagnetic waves ordered by frequency/wavelength. From long to short: radio, microwave, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays. All travel at speed of light in vacuum.
Ratio of speed of light in vacuum to speed in medium: n = c/v. Dimensionless, always ≥ 1. Measures optical density of medium. Higher n means light travels slower, more bending at interface.
Physical distance multiplied by refractive index: nd. Represents equivalent distance in vacuum for same phase change. Used in interference calculations.
Every point on wavefront acts as source of secondary wavelets. Envelope of these wavelets gives new wavefront. Explains reflection, refraction, diffraction. Foundation of wave theory of light.
Surface of constant phase in propagating wave. All points on wavefront oscillate in phase. Perpendicular to direction of propagation. Types: plane, spherical, cylindrical.

Property of maintaining constant phase relationship. Temporal coherence: phase correlation over time. Spatial coherence: phase correlation across space. Essential for clear interference patterns. Lasers highly coherent.

Orientation of oscillation perpendicular to propagation direction. Only transverse waves can be polarized. Unpolarized: oscillations in all perpendicular directions. Polarized: oscillation in single plane.
The plane containing electric field vector and direction of propagation. Light is plane-polarized when electric field oscillates in single plane.

When polarized light passes through analyzer, transmitted intensity varies as square of cosine of angle between polarizer and analyzer axes: I = I₀cos²θ. Zero transmission at 90° (crossed polarizers).
Reflected light is partially polarized, with electric field preferentially perpendicular to plane of incidence. Complete polarization at Brewster's angle. Used in polarizing sunglasses.
Angle of incidence at which reflected light is completely plane-polarized. Occurs when reflected and refracted rays are perpendicular. tan θₚ = n₂/n₁. Also called polarizing angle.

Superposition of coherent light waves producing pattern of bright and dark regions. Bright fringes: constructive interference (path difference = nλ). Dark fringes: destructive (path difference = (n+½)λ).
Classic demonstration of wave nature of light. Single source illuminates two narrow slits, producing interference pattern on screen. Bright and dark fringes prove wave behavior.
Sources must be coherent (constant phase difference), monochromatic (single wavelength), have comparable amplitudes, and should be close together relative to distance to screen.

Distance between consecutive bright (or dark) fringes in interference pattern. Directly proportional to wavelength and screen distance, inversely proportional to slit separation. Uniform spacing in double slit.
Interference between light reflected from top and bottom surfaces of thin film. Creates colorful patterns (soap bubbles, oil films). Phase change may occur at denser medium reflection.
Circular interference fringes formed between plano-convex lens and flat glass plate. Central spot usually dark due to phase change at reflection. Used to test optical surfaces and measure wavelength.
Bending of waves around obstacles or through apertures. Significant when obstacle size comparable to wavelength. Proves wave nature of light. Limits resolution of optical instruments.
Produces central bright maximum (wider and brighter) with alternating dark and bright fringes of decreasing intensity. Central maximum twice width of secondary maxima. First minimum when a sinθ = λ.
Array of many parallel slits (thousands per cm). Produces very sharp, bright interference maxima at specific angles. Used for spectroscopy - separates light into component wavelengths.
Condition for principal maxima: d sinθ = nλ, where d is grating spacing, n is order. Higher orders farther from center. Used to precisely measure wavelengths.
Ability of optical instrument to distinguish between two close objects as separate. Limited by diffraction. Better resolution requires larger aperture or shorter wavelength.
Two point sources just resolved when central maximum of one diffraction pattern falls on first minimum of other. Minimum resolvable angle θ = 1.22λ/D for circular aperture of diameter D.
Light of single wavelength (color). Pure monochromatic light doesn't exist naturally. Lasers and spectral lamps produce nearly monochromatic light. Essential for clear interference patterns.

White light contains all wavelengths. Central fringe white (all wavelengths in phase), others colored (different wavelengths satisfy maxima condition at different positions). Used in optical coatings.

Separation of white light into component colors due to wavelength-dependent refractive index. Red light least deviated (longer wavelength, lower n), violet most (shorter wavelength, higher n). Creates rainbow.
Thin film on lens surface to minimize reflection through destructive interference. Coating thickness typically λ/4 in coating material. Improves light transmission, reduces glare.
